Award.AwardTitle: CMG COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Magnetic Viscosity and Thermoremanent Magnetization in Interacting Single-domain Ferromagnets
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many major hypotheses about the geology of pre-Mesozoic eras rely critically on paleomagnetic data. Magnetic remanence in rocks records the ancient magnetic field and provides information on plate tectonics and the history of the geodynamo. For the remanence to be useful, it must remain stable as the rocks are subjected to temperature increases, pressure, and changes in the chemical environment. Suitable rocks become increasingly rare as their age increases. In pre-Mesozoic rocks, many of the most promising magnetic recorders do not fit the standard model for good paleomagnetic recorders because the magnetic minerals interact with each other through magnetic fields. If these interactions are not properly accounted for, paleomagnetic measurements can be misleading. The effect of interactions is complicated by thermal relaxation of the magnetic moments in which the magnetization jumps over energy barriers between stable states. The greatest challenge facing models of interacting magnets is to find these energy barriers.

The object of this proposal is to harness some powerful methods from numerical algebraic geometry to calculate the magnetic effects of particle interactions and thermal fluctuations. The equilibrium equations for interacting magnets can be expressed as systems of polynomial equations. Methods will be developed to find all the stable states and transition states for such systems using homotopy continuation. The time dependence of the magnetization can then be expressed as a set of kinetic equations. There will be three main applications of this theory:
1. A theory of remanence acquisition and demagnetization for titanomagnetite inclusions in sub-aerial basalts and Precambrian shields. These titanomagnetites are often networks of strongly interacting magnetite grains separated by ilmenite lamellae. The effect of particle interactions and grain growth on the accuracy of paleointensity measurements will be determined.
2. A model of isothermal hysteresis measurements of sedimentary systems involving single-domain and superparamagnetic particles that may have significant interactions. These include remagnetized carbonates, sediments with fossil magnetotactic bacteria, and sediments with greigite or pyrrhotite. Such systems can carry important information on ancient environments and human impacts.
3. A model of measurements involving oscillating fields, including anhysteretic remanent magnetization (ARM) and alternating field demagnetization of remanence. These measurements are common tools in paleomagnetic analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theory of thermoremanent magnetization (TRM) published by Louis Neel in 1949 is widely considered the most important theory in rock magnetism. It provides a mechanism for igneous rocks to be magnetized as they solidify and cool, preserving a record of the Earth's field for millions of years; and it provides a rationale for some of the most important methods in paleomagnetism.


Neel's theory uses a very simple model of a small mineral that can be in one of two magnetic states. Between them is an energy barrier. At high temperatures, thermal fluctuations can drive the magnetization over the barrier, and the mineral is superparamagnetic. At lower temperatures, the mineral is "blocked" in one of the states, preserving a magnetic moment that remains after the magnetic field is removed. The temperature at which the transition occurs is called the blocking temperature.


Neel's model mineral is far simpler than most real minerals. Attempts have been made to generalize it, but they have involved heuristics such as mean-field models that simplify the system until it behaves like a two-state system.
Now, for the first time, I have created a true generalization of Neel's theory to systems with multiple magnetic states to choose from. This greatly increases the complexity of the calculation and several challenges had to be surmounted. The most difficult challenge was finding a way to identify all the energy barriers in the system. I solved this for small numbers of interacting magnets by expressing the equilibrium equations as polynomial equations so I can find all the solutions using numerical algebraic geometry.


Another advance was my way of modeling TRM itself. The closest analogue of Neel theory would be to find all the relaxation rates and determine a blocking temperature for each. However, this is unwieldy. I use the more straightforward approach of explicitly treating TRM as a time-dependent process with a temperature function T(t), and solving for the time dependence of the magnetization.

We have been using these methods to model systems of single-domain magnets that interact magnetically with each other. Such systems have been found in most or all of the rock samples that have been used to determine the Earth's magnetic prior to the Mesozoic. By modeling such systems, we hope to understand how standard paleomagnetic methods work and whether they can provide reliable estimates of the paleofield.

 

Among the broader impacts is a contribution to the computational infrastructure: BertiniLab. This is a MATLAB interface for the numerical algebraic package, Bertini, which solves systems of polynomial equations. It can access all the tools in Bertini, including tools for finding finite-dimensional solutions and for parameter homotopy, a method that greatly increases the efficiency of the solver when finding suites of solutions that are related by one or more variable parameters. This project also provided training in numerical algebraic geometry and magnetism for a graduate student, Matt Niemerg, and he has now completed his PhD.
